posts.excerpt: Agentic systems die without feedback. We design it in from the first prototype so the agent has a rhythm: propose, check, adapt.
posts.content:
Agentic systems die without feedback. We design it in from the first prototype so the agent has a rhythm: propose, check, adapt.

Three loops we add immediately

  1. Self-checks: lightweight validators that score the agent's own work against constraints.
  2. Peer checks: a second agent (or a person) that only critiques; they never ship code.
  3. Field checks: instrumentation in production that reports back before a problem becomes user-visible.

What this changes

  • Debriefs become data-rich: we can trace which loop caught the issue.
  • Rollbacks are graceful because we plan them before we need them.
  • Trust grows; teams see the agent improve instead of drift.

The goal is not perfect autonomy—it is predictable, inspectable momentum. Feedback is the scaffolding that makes it possible.

meta.title: When agents carry their own context

posts.excerpt: Context-carrying agents behave more like teammates than macros. They remember why a decision matters, not just what the next API call should be.
posts.content:
Context-carrying agents behave more like teammates than macros. They remember why a decision matters, not just what the next API call should be.

Build the backpack

  • Thin profile: keep only the last actionable facts, not the entire chat log.
  • Anchored references: instead of dumping docs, store IDs or file paths and fetch on demand.
  • Just enough state: push state to external stores when it grows; keep the agent lean for clarity and cost.

Playbooks on rails

We give every agent a short playbook: what a good outcome looks like, the two anti-patterns to avoid, and the boundary lines. The playbook becomes a miniature contract between the agent and the operator.

Results we watch

  • Lower variance across retries because the intent stays stable.
  • Faster handoffs to humans—people see not just the output but the reasoning breadcrumbs.
  • Easier audits when we can replay the state that shaped a decision.

meta.title: Agentic AI starts with flow maps

posts.excerpt: We map agentic AI like a river delta: start from a user goal, branch into experiments, and mark where feedback loops reconnect. The first sketches live on whiteboards, but the strongest ones live alongside the codebase.
posts.content:
We map agentic AI like a river delta: start from a user goal, branch into experiments, and mark where feedback loops reconnect. The first sketches live on whiteboards, but the strongest ones live alongside the codebase.

Why mapping helps

  • Agents inherit the shape of the work we give them. Flow maps make that shape explicit.
  • They expose the critical checkpoints where we should ask a human, call a tool, or roll back.
  • They keep us honest about inputs and observability before we celebrate autonomy.

How we capture the flow

  1. Define the anchor: the user goal and its constraints.
  2. Trace the first-pass path: the happy path the agent would attempt today.
  3. Layer the guards: add sensors (telemetry), brakes (stop conditions), and rerouters (human-in-the-loop moments).
  4. Test the edges: run the map against three failure modes and keep refining.

With every revision the agent stops feeling abstract. It becomes a partner with a map, a compass, and a clear way to ask for help.
